+
Penn State has a large football following and attracts tens of thousands of visitors to its campus; the surrounding area is known as "Happy Valley" for tailgating and games on autumn Saturdays in [[Beaver Stadium]]. The stadium is the second-largest in the country with a [[seating capacity]] of over 107,282. The largest crowd ever at Beaver Stadium was on [[September 14]], [[2002]], as 110,753 watched the Nittany Lions defeat the [[University of Nebraska]] by a score of 40-7. The school has earned a reputation as "[[Linebacker]] U" for the number of high-quality linebackers trained.[http://www.collegian.psu.edu/archive/2005/04/04-22-05tdc/04-22-05dsports-06.asp] [[Joe Paterno]] has been the head coach for the Nittany Lion football team since 1966 and is regarded as one of the most successful and venerable national coaches. Penn State plays in two football "trophy games" with other members of the Big Ten. They are for the [[Governor's Victory Bell]] with the [[University of Minnesota]] and the season-ending [[Land Grant Trophy]] game versus [[Michigan State University]].
Prior to joining the Big Ten, Penn State was one of the strongest of the independent schools in college football. They played a number of schools regularly, including [[University of Pittsburgh|Pitt]], [[Syracuse University|Syracuse]], [[West Virginia University|West Virginia]], [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]], [[University of Maryland|Maryland]] and [[University of Alabama|Alabama]]. Penn State has won the prestigious [[Lambert-Meadowlands Trophy]], awarded for Eastern football supremacy, a record 26 times as of 2005.
Prior to joining the Big Ten, Penn State was one of the strongest of the independent schools in college football. They played a number of schools regularly, including [[University of Pittsburgh|Pitt]], [[Syracuse University|Syracuse]], [[West Virginia University|West Virginia]], [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]], [[University of Maryland|Maryland]] and [[University of Alabama|Alabama]]. Penn State has won the prestigious [[Lambert-Meadowlands Trophy]], awarded for Eastern football supremacy, a record 26 times as of 2005.
